section.title: Death of Charles F. Nevin
section.para: Charles Finley Nevin, of Pittsburgh, Pa., died September 9, after a lingering illness of nearly two years’ duration. Mr. Nevin was president of the T. H. Nevin Co., paint manufacturers of Pittsburgh, and was widely known as treasurer of the Paint Grinders’ Association of the United States, in which organization he was prominent. His death, though not unexpected, has made a profound impression in trade circles where he was best known and highly honored. In November, 1900, Mr. Nevin suffered a severe attack of pneu-

monia, which developed into consumption, from which he was unable to recover. Charles F. Nevin was born in Sewickley, Pa., on May 19, 1848. He was a son of Theodore H. Nevin, and with his father he organized the T. H. Nevin Company, pioneer —paint and white lead company, of which he has been president since 1870. He succeeded his father as inspector on the prison board of the Western Pennsylvania penitentiary, which office he has held ever since. In Sewickley, where his whole life has been spent he has been prominent in the church, social and political lines. For the past three terms he has been president of Sewickley borough council, holding that oﬂice at the time of his death, and he also served two previous terms with that body, in the eighties. Mr. Nevin is survived by a wife -formerly Miss Elizabeth Grafton - and two children, Theodore Hugh, a senior at Yale University, and Elizabeth, a young school girl, and a brother and sister, Franklin Taylor Nevin, Esq., of the Allegheny county bar, and Mrs. John B. Booth, of Sewickley.
